## Flight Rules

flights can be conducted under visual flight rules (VFR) or instrument flight rules (IFR)

VFR permitted in certain types of airspace, with 1 exception, only under visual meteorological conditions (VMC).    
IFR flights can be conducted in any meteorological condition (and any airspace).

### Use of Air Traffic Services

FLIGHT PLANS ~ operational flight plan required for all flights.    
ATS flight plan should be filed to permit ALERTING SERVICES to be activated, if required.    

ATC clearances are issued solely for expediting and separating air traffic and are based on known traffic conditions.    
If an ATC clearance is not suitable, the pilot-in-command may request and - if practicalbel - obtain an amended clearance.

Issuance of an air traffic control clearance constitutes authority for an aircraft to proceed only in so far as known air traffic in concerned.    
ATC clearances do not consitute authority to voilate any applicable regulations for promoting safety or for any other purpose.    
Clearances DO NOT relieve a pilot-in-command of any responsibility whatsoever in connection with a possible violation of applicable rules and regulations.

ATCU units shall issue ATC clearances as necessary to prevent collisiotns and to expedited and maintain an orderly flow of air traffic.    

If flight plan  specifies that initial portion of a flight will be uncontrolled, and that the subsequent portion of the flight will be subhect to ATC, the aircraft shall be advised to obtain ist clearance from the ATC unit in whose area controlled flight will be commenced.    
If flight plan specifies that first portion of a flight will be subject to ATC and tha the subsequent portion will be uncontrolled, the aircraft shall normally be cleared to the point at which the controlled flight terminates.

When requested and agreed by pilot of other aircraft and so authorised by appropriatee ATS authority, ATC may clear a controlled flight, including departing and arriving flights, operating in airspace class D and E in visual meteorological conditions during the hours of daylight to fly subject to maintaining own separatio to one other aircraft and remain inv VMC.    
When a controlled flight is so cleared the following shall apply:    
+ clearance shall be for a specified portion of the flight at of below 3050m/10.000ft during climb or descent and subject to further restrictions as and when prescribed on the basis of regional air navigation agreements;
+ if there is a possibility that flught under VMC may become impracticable, an IFR flight shall be provided with alternative instructions to be complied with in the event that flight in VMC cannot be maintained for the term of the clearance;
+ the pilot of an IFR flight, on observing that conditions are deteriorating and considering that VMC will become impossible, shall inform ATC before entering IMC and shall proceed in accordance with the alternative instructions given.

Provision of vertical or horizontal separation aby an ATCunit is not applicable in tespect of any specified portion of a flight cleared subject to maintianing own separation and remaining in VMC.    
If is for the flight so cleared to ensure, for the durationof the clearance, that it is not operated in such proximity to other flights as to create a collision hazard.

VFR flight must maintain in VMC at all times.    
Clearance to a VFR flight to fly subject to maintaining own separation and remaining in VMC has no other object that to signify that - for the duratio of the clearance - separation from other aircraft by ATC is not provided.

Objective of ATC do not include prevention of collision with terrain.    
The procedures prescribed do not relieve pilots of their responsibility to ensure that any clearrrances issued by ATC are safe in that respect.

### Change from VFR to IFR

ac operate in accordance with VFR wishes to change to compliance with IFR shall - if a flight plas was sub mitted - communicate the necessary changes to be effected to its current flight plan OR    
submit a flight plan to appropriate air traffic service unit and obtain a clearance prior to proceeding IFR when in controlled airspace.

### Change from IFR to VFR

ac operating under IFR encouters VMC shall not cancle its IFR flight unless it is anticipated and intended that the flight will be continued for a reasonable perriod of time in uniterrupted VMC.

Change from IFR to VFR flight shall only acceptable when a message initiated by the pilot-in-command containing the specific expressing CANCELLING MY IFR FLIGHT together with the changes, if any, to be made to the current flight plan is received by an ATS unit.    
No invitation to change from IFR to VFR shall be made by ATS either directly or by inference.

### Instrument Flight Rules

#### Applicable to all IFR flights

* aircraft equipment ~ ac shall be equipped with suitable insturments and with navigation equipment appropriate to the route to be flown and in accordance with applicable air operations legislation
* minimum levels ~ except for take-off or landing, or when specifically authorised by the approprate authority, an IFR flight shall be flown at a alevel which is not below the MINIMUM FLIGHT ALTITUDE established by the State whose territory is overflown, or where no such minimum flight altitude has been established:   
  + over high terrain or mountainous areas, at a level which is at least 600m/200ft above the highest obstacle located within 8km of the estimates position of the aircraft;
  + elsewhere than as specified above at a level which is at least 300m/1000ft above the highest obstablce located withini 8km of the estimated aircraft position.

Note: "estimated position" ~ accounts for navigational accuracy on the respective route segment, NAVAIDS available on the ground and in the aircraft.

#### TIME

time reference under IFR: UTC   
expressed in 24hours and minutes (possibly seconds) beginning at midnight.    

clocks to be within 30 seconds of UTC.    

time check myst be obtained, normally from an ATS unit, prior to operating a controlled flight and at such other times during the flight as may be necessary.

time in datalink communication: accurate to -/+ 1 second of UTC

#### AIR TRAFFIC CONTROLL CLEARANCES

ATC clearance must be obtained prior to operating a controlled flight, or a portion of a flight as a controlled flight.    
Clearance is requested by submitting a flight plan to an ATC unit.

Flight plan may cover only part of a flight, as necessary, to desribe that portionof the flight or those maneuvers which are subject to ATC.   
A clearance may cover only part of a current flight plan, as indicated in a clearance limit or by reference to specific maneuvers such as taxying, landing or taking off.

Whenever ac has requested a clearance involving priority, a report expaining the reasons for the priority should be made, but only if requested by ATC.

Europe:

* clearance expires at a certain time
* take-off not before <<time>>
* unable to clear at flight levels requested
* join airways at a particular time and place and not before <<time>>
* ATC reclearance in flight.

If prior to departure it is anticipated that depending on fuel endurance and subject to re-clearance in flight, as decision may be taken to proceed to a revised destination aerodrome, the appropriate ATC unit shall be notified  by the instertion in the flight plan of information concerning the revised route (where known) and the revised destination.

The purpose of this is to facilitate a re-clearance to a revised destination, normally beyond the filed destination aerodrome, a procedure known as the reduced contingency fuel RCF or decision point procedure.

#### Taxy Clearance

ac operated on a controlled aerodreom shall not taxy on the maneuvering area without clearance from the aerodrome control tower and shall comply with any instructions given by that unit.

#### Adherence to Flight Plan

ac should adhere to FPL route, speeds and altitudes unless a change has been requested and authorised.   
In emergency, an ac can deviate from the FPL, if the circumstances require it but the appropriate ATS unit must be told of the emergency and the deviation as soon as possible.

Unless otherwise authorised or directed by the appropriate ATC unit, controlled flights shall - in so far practicable

+ when on established ATS routes, operate along the defined centre line of that route; or
+ when on any other route, operate directly between the vaigation facilities and/or points defining that route.
+ on a route defined by 2 VORS, switch navigation guidance from the one behind to the one in front as neas as possible to any defined change-over point.

CHANGE-OVER POINTS should be established on ATS route segments defined by reference to VORs where this will assist accurate navigation along route segments.    
The estbalishment of change over points should be limited to reoute segments of 110km/60NM or more, except where the complexity of the ATS routes, the density of the navigational aids, or other technical and operational reasons warrant the establishment of change-over points on shorter route segments.

### Intended FPL Change

FPL changes must include:    

* change of cruising level ~ ac identification, requested new cruising level and speed at this level, revised time estimates (when applicable) at subsequent flight information region boundaries;
* change of route, destination unchanged ~ ac identification, flight rules, description of new route of flight including related flight plan data begining with the position from which requested change of route is to commence; revised time estimates; any other pertinent information.
* change of route AND destination changed ~ ac identification, flights rules, description of revised route of flight to revised destination aerodrome including related flight plan data, beginning with postion from which requested change of route is to commence; revised time estimates; alternate aerodromes ; and any other pertinent information.

### Weather Deterioration Below VMC

VFR flight operated as controlled flight AND unable to maintain VMC on its current flight plan shall    

* request an amended clearance enabling the aircraft to continue in VMC to destination or to an alternative aerodrome, or to leave the airspace within which an ATC clearance is required;
* if no clearance can be obtained, continue to operatie in VMC and notify the appropriate ATC unit of the action being taken either to leave the airspace concerned or to land at the nearest suitable aerodrome;
* if operated within a control zone, requrest authorisation to operate as a special VFR flight; or
* request clearance to operate in accordance with IFR.

### Position Reports - ICAO

unless exempted, a controlled flight must make position reports at each designated compulsory reporting point OR when requested.

position reports:     
+ time passing the designated reporting point
+ flight level
+ any extra information specificed with is often the ETA of the next reporting point and the name of the next reporting point beyond that.
+ speed control restrictions should be included; reported as IAS below FL250, above as Mach number

controlled flights providing postion reports via datalink need only provide voice position reports when requested

if specified in PANS-ATM, SSR mode C transmission of pressure altitude satisfy the requirement for level information in position reports.

### Position Reports - Europe

In EU region, postion reports should contain aircraft identification, position, time, and flight level, unless otherwise specified.

areas with reliable radio communication, pilot and ATS unit and where SSR labels and Mode C information are permanently displayed to ATCO, the initial call need only contain the aircraft identification and level, subsequent position reports, if required, need only include identification, postion, and time.

### Termination of Control

A controlled flight shall - except when landing at a controlled aerodroeome - advise the appropriate ATC unit as soon as it ceases to be subject to Air Traffic Controll services.

### Communications

ac operated as controlled flight must maintain continuous air-ground voice communication watch on the appropriate communication channel of, and establish 2-way communication as necessary with, the approprate Air Traffic Control unit excpet as may be prescribed by the appropriate ATS Authority in respect of ac forming part of aerodrome traffic at a controlled aerodrome.

SELCAL or similar automatic signalling devices satisfy the requirement to maintain air-ground voice communication watch.

If using controller-pilot data link communication CPDLC, the requirement for air-ground communication watch remains in effect after CPDLC has been established (to ensure voice for fallback/emergency).

EUROPE   ~ all ac operating above FL195 in EUR region must be quipped with 8.33kHz channel spacing.    
ac operationg in uncontrolled airspace may be required to maintain a listening watch on specified frequencies.

### Communication Failure

ac fails to maintain or etablish contact with aeronautical station, try another frequency.     
if atttempt fails, attempt contact other ac appropriate freqs or 121.5 MHz, including the air-to-air frequency 123,45MHz.

if this fails:     
- SQUAWK 7600 and if ADSB equipped - select COMMUNICATION FAILURE
_ transmit its messages twince on the designated frequency(s) preceded by the phrase "TRANSMITTING BLING" and - if necessary - include the addressee(s) for which the message is intended; and
- intention of the pilot

subsequent actions should be:     
* continue in VMC
* land at the nearest suitable aerodrome; keep watch for visual signals
* report the arrival by the most expeditious means to ATC.

if IMC or when conditions are such that it is not feasible to complete the flight in accordance with VFR, then

IMC or IFR - NO RADAR SERVICE    
unless otherwise prescribed on the basis of regional air navigation agreement, in airspace where radar is not used in the provision of ATC:    

* maintain the last assigned speed and level OR minimum flight altitude if higher
* for a period of 20 minutes following the ac's failure to report its position over a complusory reporting point, AND
* thereafter adjust flight level and speed in accordance with filed flight plan

IMC or IFR AND RADAR SERVICE AVAILABLE    
in airspace where radar is used in ATC:     

* maintain the last assigned speed and level, or the minimum safe altitude if higher
* for a period of 7 minutes; 7 minutes start from
  + point when the transponder is set to 7600, 
  + the last assigned level is reached, or
  + the time the aircraft failed to make the last compulsory position report, whichever is LATER
* when being radar vectored or having been directed by ATC to proceed offset without a specified limit, rejoin the current flight plan in the most direct manner possible and no later than the next significant point.

### EU Differences

IFR flights 

* maintain the last assigned speed and level for 20 minutes after squawking 7600, if failure occurs outside controlled airspace;
* then proceed according to filed flight plan;
* if not limit points specified, rejoin the flight plan route at the next significant point.

Where PIC of an IFR flight encounters VMC and elects to continue to fly in VMC, the pilot will set Mode A code 7601 in EU airspace

IMC or IFR - subsequent actions

* follow the flight plan to destination and enter the hold at the designated NAVAID; commence the approach as close as possible to the last acknoweledged expected approach time EAT. if not EAT has been received and acknowledged then commenct tha approach as close as possible to flight plan ETA;
* complete a normal instrument approach;
* if possible land within 30 minutes of the latest EAT or flight ETA, whichever is later.

### Action by ATC

loss of 2-way communication, ATS unit will use all available means to contact the aircraft including 121.5MHz, relays and SELCAL.

ATCO should determine whether or not the ac's receiver is functioning by instructing the ac on the channel by making a specified maneuver or by instructin the ac tsquakw IDENT or make SSR code and/or SDSB transmission changes.

Note: ac to squwak 7600     
ADSB equipped ac may transmit appropriate ADSB emergency and/or urgency mode

ATCO to repeat on any other available channel on which it is believed that the ac might be listening.   

In both cases any maneuvering instructions shall be such that the ac would regain its current cleared track after having complied with the instructions received.

When established that ac radio receiver is functioning, continued control can be effected using SSR code/ADSB transmission changes or IDENT to obtain acknowledgement of clearances.

### Complete Communication Failure

When ac experiencing complete communication failure and operates within area and flgith levels wehre an ATS surveillance service is applied, NORMAL SEPARATION rules may continue to be used.

If ac experiencing communication failure is NOT IDENTIFIED, separation between identified ac and all unidentified ac observed along the expected route of the ac with failure, until such time as it is known, or can safely be assumed, that the ac with failure has passed through the airspace concerned, has landed, or has proceeded elsewhere.    
ATCO will increase separation to an acceptable (judgemental) level. (?!?!?!?)

### IFR flight within Controlled Airspace

IFR flights shall be subject to ATC when operated in controlled airspace.

cruising levels ~ IFR in controlled airspace must be operated at appropriate FLD.   
in cruise climb, it must operate either between 2 IFR cruising levels or above an IFR flight level.    
for flights above FL410, the correlation beteen track direction and crusing level can be overriden by an ATC clearance or by the national AIP.

### IFR Flights Outside Controlled Airspace

cruising levels - IFR operating in level cruising flight outside of controlled airspace shall be flown at a cruising level appropriate to it track.   
This provision does not preclude the use of cruise climb techniques by ac in supersonic flight.

above FL410, other cruising levels may be flown, if authorised.

communications - IFR flight operating outside controlled airspace but within or into areas, or along routes, designated by the appropriate ATS Authority shall maintain an air-ground voice communication watch on the approprate communication channel and establish 2-way communication, as necessary, with the air traffic service unity providing Flight Information Service.

position reports - IFR flight operationg outside controlled airspace and required by the appropriates ATS Authority

* submit FPL
* maintain air-gorund voice communication watch on the appro channen and establish 2 way communication, as necessary with the air traffic service ... FIS AND MAKE POSITION REPROTS as if it was a controlled flight.

ac electing to use air traffic advisory srevice whilest operation IFR within specified advisory airspace are also expected to make position reports, ecept the flight plan and changes thereto are not subjected to clearances and that 2-way communication will be maintained with the unit providing the air traffic advisory service.

### EMERGENCY DESCENT

ATC 

+ broadcast by means of appropriate radio aides, or if not possible, request the appropriate commuincation stations immediately to bradcast an emergency message

OTHER AC    

it is expected that ac receiving such broadcast will clear the specified areas and stand by on the appropriate radio frequency for further clearances from the ATC unit

subsequent action by ATC

after emergency broadcast has been made, the ACC, Approach Unit, or aerodrome control tower concerned shall forward further clearances to all ac involved as to additional procedures to be followed during and subsequent to the emergency descent.   
THe ATS unit concerned shall additonally inform any other ATS units and control sectors which may be affected.


## Rules of the Air

Departures from Rules of the Air is ONLY PERMITTED in the interest of Flight Safety.

PRE-FLIGHT ACTION

before a flight, PIC to familiarise with ALL AVAIBLE information.   
For flights away from aerodrome, and for all IFR flights, CAREFUL STUDY of available weather reports and forecasts, taking into account fuel requirements, and alternative course of action if the flight cannot be complemented as planned.

SIMULATED INSTRUMENT FLIGHT

ac shall not be flown under simulated instrument flight conditions, i.e., with screens or equivalent, UNLESS    
* fully functioning dual controls are installed in the ac; AND
* a qualified pilot occupies a control-seat to as as SAFETY PILOT for the person flying under simulated instrument conditions.
* safety pilot shall have adequate vision forward and to each side of the ac, or a compentent observer in cummunication with the safety pilot shall occupy a position in the aircraft from which the observer's field of vision adequately supplements that of the safety pilot.

FLIGHT PLANS

a flight plan SHALL be SUBMITTED priort to operating   

* any flight or portion thereof to be provided with an air traffic control service;
* any IFR flight within advisory airspace;
* any flight within or into areas, or along routes designated by the competent authority, to facilitate the provision of flight information, alerting, and search and rescue services;
* any flight within or into areas, or along routes designated by the competent authority, fo facilitate coordination with appropriate military units or with air traffic srevices units in adjacent States in order to avoid the possible need for interception for the purpose of identification;
* any flight across international borders, unless otherwise prescribed by the States concerned; or
* any flight planned to operate at night, if leaving the vicinity of an aerodrome.

Note: not mandatory, but "highly recommended", file flight plans for flights over water greater than 10NM from the coast and/or flight over sparsely populated or remote terrain.

WHERE TO FILE FPL

FPL to be sumbitted BEFORE DEPARTURE to an air traffic service reporting office or, DURING FLIGHT, transmitted to the appropriate air traffic serves unit or air-ground control radio station, unless arrangements have been made for submission of repetititve flight plans.

WHEN TO FILE FPL

unless otherwise prescribed, a FPL for a flight to be provided with ATC service or air traffic advisory service shall be submitted AT LEAST 60 minutes before departure.

if submitted during flight, it must reach the appropreate air traffic services at least 10 minutes before the ac is estimated to reach    
* the intended point of entry into a control area or adisory area; or
* the point of crossing an airway or adisory route.

CONTENT OF FPL

ICAO FPL format

flight rules: I (IFR), V (VFR), Y (IFR changing to VFR), Z (VFR changing to IFR)    

crusing speed: TAS in km/hr, e.g. K0505 for 505km/hr) or knots, e.g. N0480kts for 480kts, or Mach number, e.g. M0750 for Mach 0.750. Changes in speed of more than 5% of TAS or more of M0.01 or more must be indicated.    

"estimated elapsed time" (EET) means time from take-off to     
* for IFR flights the time at which it is estimated that the ac will arrive over that designated point, defined by reference to navigation aids, from which it is intended that an instrument approach procedure will be commenced, or - if no navigation aid is associated with the aerodrome - the time at which the ac will arriver over the aerodrome.     
* for VFR flights, the time at which it is estimated that the ac will arrive over the aerodrome.     

ZZZZ if departure, alternate, or destination aerodromes do not have an ICAO location indicator, insert ZZZZ in the appropriate section and in Field 18 provide information DEP/..., DEST/..., or ALTN/... := ... aerodrome name


CHANGES TO A FLIGHT PLAN

IFR flight: ALL changes to the flight plan    
VFR flight operated as controlled flight: changes to be reports ASAP to appropriate air traffic service unit    
other (:= uncontrolled) VFR flight: significant changes to a flight plan shall be reported ASAP to appropriate ATSU

DELAY of 30 minutes in excess of estimated off-block time EOBT for a controlled flight    
DELAY of 60 minutes for an uncontrolled flight    
flight plan should be amended or a new FPL shall be submitted and the old plan cancelled whichever is applicable.



CLOSING A FPL

unless otherwise prescribed, a report or arrival shall be made in person, by RT, or via data link at the earliest possible moment after landing, to the appropriate ATS unit at the arrival aerodrome, by any flight for which a FPL was submitted covering the entire flight or the remaining portion of a flight to the destination aerodrome.

Note:     

* not required after landing on aerodrome with ATS AND radio communication or visual signals indicate that the landing has been observed.
* if flight plan submitted for portion of flight, other than the remaining portion of a flight to destination, it shall, when required, be closed by an appropriate report to the relevant ATS unit.
* when no ATSU exists at the arrival aerodrome, the arrival report, when required, shall be made as soon as practicable after landing and bu the quickest mens available to the nearest ATSU.

if COM facilities at arrival aerodrome are inadequate and alternate arrangements for the handling of arrival reports on the ground are not available:    
* immediately prior to landing - if practicable - transmit to the appropriate ATSU, a message comparable to an arrival report, where such a report is required.    
Normally, this transmission shall be made to the aeronautical station serving the ATSU in charge of the flight information region in which the ac is operated.

Arrival reports require the following:     

* aircraft identification
* departure aerodrome
* destination aerodrome (only in case of diversionary landing)
* arrival aerodrome
* time of arrival


EUR differences

* repetitive FPL may only be used for IFR flights operated regularly on the same day(s) of consecutive weeks and on at least 10 occasions or for flights on at least 10 consecutive days.
* flights subject to air traffic flow control, require flight plans to be submitted at least three hours in advance and any changes to EOBT in excess of 15 minutes requires the flight plan to be delayed or changed.

### Airspace Class Boundaries

where airspace classes adjoin vertically, i.e., the one above the other, flights on the boundery level are treated as being in the less restrictive class of airspace.

In applying these criteria, Class B airspace is considered less restrictive than Class A airspace, B > C ....

## Annex 11 - Air Traffic Services

Annex 11 - division of airspace & SARPS for ATS  

APPLICATION ~ where Contracting States provide air traffic services ATS SARPs apply, i.e., sovereign airspace and over high seas or undetermined sovereignty (and serviced by a specific CS).

standard := essential mandatory    
recommended practices := non-mandatory (i.e., expected)     
Annex 11 comprises a large number of recommended practices (non-mandatory) ~ regional variations to be notified to ICAO (and the world)

### Air Traffic Control Service ATC

units providing ATC are: area control centre ACC (service en-route flights), approach control office APP (service controlled flights during arrival or departure), and control Tower TWR (aerodrome traffic)

area control service (ACS) - can provide approach control service    
approach control sercice (APP) -> dedicated arrival/deprature servcice; can be offered by TWR or ACC    
aerodrome control service (TWR) -> tower, apron service may be assigned to a separate unit.

### Operation of Air Traffic Control Service

an ATC unit must    

* be provided with information on the intended movement of each aircraft, and with current information on the actual progress of each ac;
* determine from the information received, the relative positions of known ac to each other;
* issue clearances and information for the purpose of preventing collisions between ac under its control and of expediting and maintaining an orderly flow of air traffic;
* coordinate clearances as necessary with other unites
  + whenever an ac might otherwise conflict with traffic operated under the control of such other traffic
  + before transferring control of an ac to such other units.
  
UTC time used worldwide for ATS purposes; accurate to -/+ 30 secs.

### Separation of Aircraft

ATS := prevent collision of ac => vertical or horizontal separation

vertical separation to ac in cruise by procedrues specific to their area; e.g. semi-circular cruising levels at/below FL410, modified tables of cruising levels may be used above FL410.

horizontal separation is achieved by spacing ac laterally or longitudinally, or combination to horizontal and longitudinal.

regional agreements allow the use of both horizontal and vertical separation together, called composite separation.   
composite separation ~ horizontal and vertical requirements can be reduced bu never to less than half the standard values

separation minima are published in PANS-ATM with variations notified in reginal supplements.

### Longitudinal Separation

EUR - variation from ICAO standard longitudinal separation.

ac at level, climbing, or descending to be separated by 3 minutes, provided that     
+ progress is continously monitored by radar,
+ radar separation is never less than 20NM.

applying assigned mach number for ac on same track and level provided that
+ both ac are observed on radar and no interruption to the service is anticipated;
+ ac operating at assinged Mach numbers and the following ac is assinged the same or a lower Mach number than the lead

### ATC clearance

ALL controlled traffic subject to ATC clearance.   
ATC clearance is defined as "authorisation for an aircraft to proceed under conditions specified by ATC unit".

ATC clearances to ac in flight, and ac and vehicles on the ground.

ATC clearance should indicate:    

* ac identification (as shown in FPL)
* clearance limit
* route of flight
* level(s) of flight for the entire route or part thereof, and changes of levels if required; and
* any necessary instructions or information on the other matters such as approach or departure maneuvers, communications, and the time of expire of the cleaance.

### Responsibility of the Aircraft Commander (Pilot in Command)

ATC clearance should USUALLY be OBEYed, but it does not absolve the ac commander of his or her responsibility to comly with the rules of the air and safety of ac.    
Aircraft commander may advise ATC that the ac is unable to comly with a clearance and, in extreme cases, reject a clearance which is believed to be unsafe.   

When being radar vectored, an ATC clearance shoudl take into account obstacle clearance.

READING BACK CLEARANCES     
clearance should be read back, usually in FULL, so that receipt and understanding are confirmed.

unless specified by the authority, voice readback of CPDL messages is not required.

RADIO COMMUNICATIONS     
ac must maintain 2-way communication with current ATC unit whilst receiving a clearance from another unit which is further down the route.

COORDINATING ATC CLEARANCES     
responsibility for (en)route clearances lies with ACC in which flight begins.

ACC to coordinate clearance, in particular for flights about to shortly after take off leaving AOR (<30 minutes).

if (ever) coordination is incomplete and a clearance limit is reached, it is the responsibility of the PIC to obtain on-going clearance before proceeding beyojnd the clearance limit.

### Air Traffic Flow Management ATFM

ATFM in Europe to optimise the flow of air traffic.    
ATFM is available to all States in the EUR region.

ATFM may be applied to flights that      
+ take place in the EUR region
+ depart from the EUR region; or
+ enter the EUR region from an adjacent FIR.

Where ATFM is applied, there is a requirement to file flight plans well in advance and you may anticipate slot times to be issued for the departure.

Certain flights may be given priority over other flights, and certain flights may be exempt from the requirement to obtain a slot.

### Automatic Terminal INformation ATIS broadccasts

voice-ATIS or D-ATIS; D-ATIS transmitted to ac's FMS, electronic flight bag, or multi-function display

VOICE-ATIS ~ provided at busy aerodromes to reduce voice frequency load; typically    
* a single broadcast serving arriving ac; or
* a single broadcast serving departing ac; or
* one broadcast serving both, arriving and departing, ac; or
* two separate broadcasts on different frequencies serving arriving and depating ac respectively. Note: used when length of a single broadcast serviing both arriving and departing ac would be excessively long.

discrete VHF frequency - whenever practicable - to be used for voice-ATIS broadcasts.    
if no discrete VHF frequency available, the transmission may be on the voice channels of the most appropriate terminal NAVAID(s), preferably a VOR, provide the range and readability are adequate and the identification of the NAVAID is sequenced with the broadcast so that the latter is not obliterated.   
Voice-ATIS broadcasts will not be transmitted on the voice channel of an ILS.

Whenever voice-ATIS is provided, the broadcast should be continuous and repetitive, and is often also generated by text-to-speech software.   
It is recommended to not exceed 30 seconds.

CONTENTS OF ATIS BROADCAST    
* relate to a single aerodrome
* individual ATIS messages will be identified by a letter designator, e.g. "This is information GOLF, ..."
* information should be updated immediately when a significant change occurs, the identifyer is then changed to the next letter in the alphabet.
* ac must acknowledge receipt of the information upon establishing communication with ATS unit providing either the approach control service or aerodrome control service, as appropriate.
* when replying, the ATS unit need not retransmit any information contained in the ATIS to the ac except for the altimeter setting, which is always transmitted.
* if an ac acknowledges receipt of an ATIS that is not longer current, any element of information that needs updating shall be transmitted to the ac without delay.

## Emergency Procedures

**alterting service** := a service provided to notify appropriate organisations regarding airraft in need of search and rescue aid, and assist such organisation as required.   
Annex 11 sets out requirement for alerting service    
Annex 12 sets out search and rescue operations

### Service to Aircraft in the Event of an Emergency

aircraft to be known or believed in a state of emergency, including being subjected to unlawful interference, shall be given maximum consideration, assistance, and priority over other aircraft as may be cessitated by the circumstatnces.

A pilot may be expetcted to be contacted by ATS on 121.5MHz, or even 243.0MHz, in an emergency, assuming that communication attempts on the frequency in use have been unsucessful.

Aircraft equipped with an appropriate data link capability and/or an SSR transpointer might indicate an emergency, by operating the quipment as follows:

* Mode A, code 7700 := emergency or interception by a military ac
* Mode A, code 7500 := ac subject to unlawful interference
* activate the appropriate emergency capability of ADS
* transmit the appropriate emergency message via CPDLC.

### 3 Phases of Emergency

ATSU shall inform rescue coordination centers immediately when an ac is considered to be in a state of emergency according to 3 defined phases, or states of emergency:

* uncertainty phase ~ a situation where uncertainty exists as to the safety of an aircraft and its occupants;
* alert phase ~ a situation where apprehension exists as to the safety ofa an ac and its occupants; or
* distress phase ~ a situation where there is reasonable certainty that an ac and its occupants are threatened by grave and imminent danger or require immediate assistance.

Phases are initiated when certain set criteria are complied with.

ac flown at altitudes determined from an altimeter set to sea level pressure QNH when at or below the TRANSITION ALTITUDE. vertical position expressed in terms of altitude.

flights above transition altitude are performed along surfaces of constant atmospheric pressure baed on altimeter setting of 1013.25hPa (= mb) := flight levels.  
Flight levels are defined according to their height in feet in the standard atmosphere, e.g. 3500ft ~ FL35, 10.000ft ~ FL100.

where no transition altitude is established (e.g. remote areas outside FIRs), ac in the en-route phase MUST be flown at a flight level.

height above ground/AGL ~ QFE     Height    
height above mean sea level ~ QNH Altitude
height above standard pressure ~ QNE/1013.25hPa FL

altimeter settings provided to aircraft shall be rounded down to the nearest lower whole hectopascal.

### Transition Altitude TA

transition altitude is the altitude below which the vertical position of the aircraft is controlled by altitudes above mean sea level, i.e. QNH.

Transitiona altitude must normally be specified for each aerodrome by the State in which the aerodrome is located.   
In practice - and to avoid confusion - transitiona altitudes are normally standardised for the whole FIR.

Whereas the transition altitude is fixed, the transition level will change as the value of the QNH changes and ATC are responsible for calculating the transition level to be used.

The calculated height of the transition altitude is rounded up to the next full 1000ft, thus a calculated transition altitude (level?) of 33ooft will become 4000ft.

Transitional altitudes are published in the AIP and also shown on appropriate charts.

Transition altitude of an aerodrome shall be as low as possible, but not nromally less than 3000ft AGL.

### Transition Level TRL

change in reference from altitude on QNH to flight levels on 1013.2hPa is made when climbing, at the transition altitude.

when descending towards the transition altitude this is more difficult as the altimeters will be set to 1013.2hPa and the ac altitude may not be known.

To make things simple a transition level TRL, which is the lowest flight level available for use above the transition altitude, will be passed to a descending aircraft, normally as part of an approach or landing clearance, but can be requested by the pilot.   
An ac in descent must set QNH at the transition level.

Transition altitude := altitude at which the pilot in a climb changes altimeter setting from QNH to 1013.2hPa.    
Transition level := lowest flight level available for use above the transition altitude. = flight level at which the pilot in a descent changes altimeter setting from 1013.2hPa to QNH.  

### Transition Layer

transition layer := layer between transition altitude and transition level.

during passage of transition layer    
- vertical position expressed in terms of flight levels for ascending ac; and
- in terms of altitude for descending ac.

variations to this procedure exists in various countries:    
pilot in descending ac from FL to ALT, the pilot will change to the aerodrome QNH unless further flight level vacating reports have been requested by ATC, in which case the QNH will be set following the final flight level vacation report.

here ATCOs need to realise that the datum will have been changed, and be repared to act accordingly.

Pilots followin this procedure must be aware of the consequences in countries where this procedure is not standard, if the controller requires the ac to level before the cleared altituge is reached.    
For example, ac cleared to descend from FL100 to ALT 3000feet, transition level FL40.   => pilot will set QNH and commence descent.   
If controller subsequently requires the ac to level at FL60, the standard pressure setting must be reset!

## SSR Operating Procedures

SSR -> ac equipped with transponder -> reply to (ground) interrogation

Mode A  4096 numerical codes; 0-7    
Mode C  pressure altitude in 100ft/FL increments    
Mode S  transmits Mode A and "additional information" (e.g. ac identifier [callsign or registration], level information in 25ft increments, transponder capability and SI-code capability) := **elementary suveillance mode ELS**

**enhanced surveillance mode EHS** transmits additional ac parameters, e.g. rate of climb/descent, IAS, heading, track.

IDENT     
ATC instruction: SQUAWK xxxx (= select Mode A or IDENT) ~ instruction to be acknowledged by aircrew.

**airborne collision avoidance system ACAS** uses Mode S SSR equipment.

### Operation of Transponders

when ac carries serviceable transponder, aircrew to operate the transponder at all times during flight, regardless whether ac is within or outside airspace where SSR is used for ATS purposes.

Mode A ~ except in emergencies, communication failure, or unlawful interference:   

* operate transponder selcting on of the 4096 Mode A codes as individually directed by the ATC unit with which in contact;
* operate transponder on Mode A codes as prescribed on the basis of regional air navigation agreements; or
* in the absence of any ATC instructions or regional air navigation agreements, operate the transponder on Mode A Code 2000.

Mode C ~ to be operated continuously, unless otherwise instructed by ATC.

ATC may instruct to turn mode C off, if the reported flight level differes from the actual flight level by more than 300ft or 200ft in RVSM airspace (and also in some non-RVSM airspaces in Europe).

If mode C is operated and a pilot is asked to report the ac's altitude, the level must be reported to the nearest 100ft.   
E.g. ac at 17.278ft -> reported as FL173 (17.300ft)

Mode S ~ IFR traffic in Europe with a MTOM ? 5700kg or a maximum cruising of greater than 250kt MUST be equipped with Mode S EHS.    
Other IFR traffic must be Mode S ELS compliant.

Requirements for VFR traffic vary across States, usually Mode S ELS.

IDENT ~ pilot shall not squawk ident unless requested by ATC

Equipment -> older transponders allow to turn altitude reporting on and off, or select modes. Modern equipment is build to operate at its highest capability (e.g. responding to Mode A, Mode S, and Mode C interrogations as required) ALL THE TIME.   
Typically, pilot controls restricted to IDENT, OFF/STBY/ON, and number keypad for Mode A codes.

### Transponder Failure

in case of transponder failure, ATC units shall endeavour to provide for continuation of the flight to the destination aerodrome in accordance with the FPL.   
Pilot may, however, expect to comply with specific restrictions:

In case of transpoder failure BEFORE departure, pilots shall    

* inform ATS asap, preferably before submission of a flight plan;
* insert in Item 10/FPL under SSR the character "N" for complete unserviceability of the transponder, or, in case of partial transponder failure, the character corresponding to the remaining transponder capability;
* comply with any published procedures for seeking exemption from the requirements for carriage of a functioning SSR transponder; and
* if so required by the appropriate ATS authority, plan to proceed, as directly as possible, to the nearest suitable aerodrome where repain can be effected.


SSR equipment codes for Item 10/FPL:    
N ~ NIL    
A ~ transponder - Mode A "only"    
C ~ transponder - Mode A and C    
X ~ transponder - Mode S without identification or altitude information    
P ~ transponder - Mode S altitude, but no identification information    
I ~ transponder - Mode S identification, but no altitude information    
S ~ transponder "works" - Mode S with identification or altitude information

upon TA, aircrew to try to visually identify the ac that triggered TA and prepare for an ensuing RA.

VSI
