## ICAO Doc 4444 - Air Traffic Services

Doc 4444 - Procedures for Air Navigation Services - Air Traffic Management PANS-ATM.
PANS-ATM is complementary to Annex 2 SARPs (Rules of the Air) and Annex 11 (Air Traffic Services).

### Applicability

Strictly speaking: States are NOT OBLIGED to comply with PANS-ATM ~ most do.

PANS-ATM specifies in greater detail the actual procedures to be applied by ATSUs.   
PANS-ATM procedures are supplemented where necesary by regional procedures.

PANS-ATM mainly directed at ATCOs, attention of pilots should be drawn to the portions that affect pilots/direct interest to them.

### Terrain Clearance

Annex 11 defines the objectives of ATS NOT TO INCLUDE prevention of collision with terrain.   
PANS-ATM do not relieve the pilot of his responsibilities of ensuring that any clearance issued by ATC are safe in this respect, ecept when an IFR flight is vectored by radar (radar minimum safe altitude)

### ATFM Service

ATFM ~ ensures that the number of flights does not exceed capacity of ATS.    

ATCU to inform other ATCUs about constraints (cannot accept additional traffic or only at certain entry rate).

Pilots of ac detined to the location or area in question, and operators known or believed to be concerned, must also be advised of the delays expected of the restrictions that will be applied.

### Submission of a FPL

except of arrangements for the submission of repetitive flight plans, a flight plan submitted prior to departure should be submitted to ATS reporting office at the departure aerodrome.   
If no such unit exists at the departure aerodrome, the flight plan should be submitted to the unit serving or designated to serve the departure aerodrome.

ICAO Annex 2 (rules of the air) requires flight plans to be submitted 60 minutes before departure (Europe 3 hours).   
In case of a delay of 30 minutes in excess of the EOBT for a controlled flight (or 60mins for uncontrolled flight for which FPL was submitted), FPL to be amended or a a new FPL while old FPL cancelled (whichever is applicable).

Repetitive FPL may be filed for identical flights taking place on the same day, days of consecutive weeks, and/or occur on at least ten occasions, or takel place on at least ten consecutive days.

European region: More restrictions on repetivite FPLS ~ EUR SUPPS, section 2.

### Clearances and INformation

clearances are based on known traffic conditions   -> ac in air, ac and vehicles, and  obstruction on maneuvering area and under control by ATC

ATC clearance not suitable to the PIC, PIC may request if applicable to obtain an mended clearance.

receipt of a clearance does not constitute authority to violate any applicable regulations.  

*Cleared via flight plan route* may be used to describe any route, or portion thereof, provided it is the same as that filed in the (last) FPL and that sufficient routing details are given to etablish the ac on its route.

*cleared via (designation) departure* or *cleared via (designaion) arrival* may be used when standard departure or arrival routes have been established by the appropriate ATS authority and published in the AIP.

### Multi-Stage Flights

FPL for multi-state flight with one or more intermediate stops.   
Initial clearance limit will be no further than the first destination aerodrome.   
New clearances must be obtained for each subsequent leg.

### Content of ATC Clearance

ATC to include (in order listed):    

* aircraft identification
* clearance limit
* route of flight
* level for either the entire route of for part of it and level changes if required
* instructions or other information about SSR, approach or departure procefures, communications, and the time of expiry of the clearance. If expiry time is given, the ac is not airborne by that time, a new clearance must be obtained.

E.g. London centre clears Easy443 to destination as filed, request level changes en-route.   
Bogeyair, direct SAM then ORTAC, maintain FL410. Clearance limit ORTAC, delays in xxx airspace.



### Reading Back ATC Clearances

clearance must be read back to the ATCO to confirm correct reception.   
Readback is verbatim, but the following items must always be read back

* ATC route clearances,
* clearances to enter, land-on, take-off from, hold short of, cross, taxy, or backtrack on any runway
* runway in use
* altimeter setting
* SSR codes
* level, heading, and speed instructions.

### Changes to FPL

whenissueing a clearance covering a requested change in flight plan route or cruising level, ATC must specify the exact nature of the change in the clearance.

If a level change is involved and more than one level is contained in the flight plan, all such levels must be included in the clearance.

ATCU may ask an ac to temporarily change its call sign for safety reasons when there is a risk of confuston between two or more similar call signs.

### Postion Reports

on routes defined by designated significant points, position reports must be made when over, or as soon as possible after passing, each desgnated compulsory reporting point, unless position reporting is not required.

Additional reports over other points may be requested by the appropriate air traffic services unit when so required or air traffic services purposes.

Position report should contain the following elements:

* ac identification
* position
* time
* flight level or altitude
* next position and time over
* ensuring significant point

Qanta 010A, KEMPTEN 52, FL390, estimate TANTO01, KARLSRUHE next

Flight level or altitude may be omitted on the instructions of ATC when SSR mode C information can be made continuously availbale to controllers in a labelled form, and when adepquate procedures have been developed to guarantee the safe and efficient use of SSR Mode C information.

All the last three element may be omitted from position report when so prescribed on the basis of regional air navigation agreements.

Flight level or altitude shall however be included in the initial call after changing to a new frequency.

Regional authorities may exempt certain flights completely fomr the requirement to make position reports.   
This is now normal when receiving a radar service.

### Change from IFR to VFR Flight

change form IFT to VFR is only acceptable when a message initiated by the PIC containing **cancelling my IFR flight** together with the changes, if any, to be made to his current flight plan, is received by an air traffic services unit.

No invitation to change from IFR to VFR is to be made by ATC either directly or by inference. 

No reply, other than the acknowledgement "IFR cancelled at <<time>>" should be normally made by an air traffic services unit.

When ATC are aware that IMC is likely to be encoutered along the route of flight, a pilot changing from ifR to VFR should, if practicable, be so advised.

### Wake Turbulence Categories

wake turbulence separation minima is based on a grouping of ac types into four categories according to the maximum certificated take-off mass:

* SUPER (J)   A380-800
* HEAVY (H)   ac of 136.000kg or more
* MEDIUM (M)  ac of less than 136.000kg, but more than 7000kg
* LIGHT (L)   ac of 7000kg or less

H,M,L to be entered as wake turbulence category in the FPL.

### Cruising Levels

except when specifically authorised by the appropriate authority, cruising levels below the minimum flight altitudes established by the State MUST NOT BE ASSIGNED.

minimum sector altitude MSA is calculated ensuring at least 300m/984ft clearance above the highest obstacle within 25NM of VOR, DME, or airfield.

Unless otherwise prescribed by the State concerned, the lowest usable flight level is that flight level which corresponds to, os is immediately above the established minimum flight altitude.

For flight in the vicinity of aredromes and wihtin terminal control areas, the vertical position of aircraft shall be expressed in terms of altitude at or below the transition altitude and interms of flight levels at or above the transition level.   
While passing through the trtainsiton layer, vertical position shall be expressed in terms of flight levels when climbing or in terms of altitudes when descending.

assignment of cruising levels ~ ac flying in the same direction shall be assigned in a manner that will be correct for an approach sequence t destination.

speed control ~ ATC may instruct ac to modify their speed either in the en-route or approach stages.   
At of above FL250: speed adjustments in increments of 0.01 Mach    
Below FL250: speed adjustments in increments of 10kt IAS.   
For turbine powered ac, speed reductions below 250kt may be rejected by the pilot for "good reason" (flight safety, operational performance limits/maeuverability/safe speeds)

Under radar control and on final approach speed adjustments will be limited to a maximum of 20kt.   
ONce within 4NM of the threshold on the approach no further speed adjustments should be given.


## Separation

controlled traffic is separated either vertically, horizontally, or by a combination of the two using no less than half of each criteria known as composite separation.

separation must be provided    

* between all flights in Class A and B
* between IFR flights in Class C, D, and E
* between IFR flights and VFR flights in Class C
* between IFR flights and Special VFR flights; and
* between Special VFR flights, when required by ATC, except in D and E during the hours of the daylight when flights have been cleared to climb or descend subject to maintaining own separation and remaining in VMC

procedural control := separation may be estalished by applying procedures which do not require radar surveillance, or     
radar control := by observing position of the ac on the radar screen.

procedural separation always involves greater distances between ac than radar separation.

### Procedural Separation

vertical separation obtained by requiring ac using prescribed altimeter setting procedures to operate at different levels or altitudes.

minimum vertical separation is:   

* within RVSM airspace between FL290 and FL410 inclusive: 1000ft
* below FL290: 1000ft, 
* above FL290 in non-RVSM airspace: 2000ft

vertical separation during climb or descent: pilot in direcet communication with each other may, with their concurrence, be cleared to maintain a specified vertical separation between their ac during climb or descent.     
When an ac will pass through the level of another ac on the same track, the following longitudinal separation shall be provide:   

* 15 minutes while vertical separation does not exist;
* 10 minutes while vertical separation does not exist WHEN NAVAIDS permit the frequent determination of position; or
* 5 minutes while vertical separation does not exist provided that the level change is commenced within 10 minutes of the time the 2nd ac has reported over an exact reporting point.

an ac may be assigned a level previously occupied by another ac after the latter has reported vacating it.   
if using SSR Mode C, the controller considers a lavel vacated, if it indicates a change in the anticipated direction from its previously assigned level of more than 300ft.

An ac may be cleared to a level previously occupied by another ac after the latter has reported vacating it, except when:   

* severe turbulence is known to exist;
* the higher ac is effecting a cruise climb; or
* the difference in ac performance is such that less than the applicable separation minimum may result.

In such cases, the clearance shall be withheld unti the ac vacating the level has reported at or passing another level separated by the required minimum.   
ac wishing to dscent to FL150 with another one below it wishing to descend to FL140:    
in severe turbulenes: no cleard to leave FL150 until lower ac has cleared FL130.

### Horizontal Separation

lateral & longitudinal

lateral separation of ac at the same level is obtained by requiring them to operate on different tracks or in different locations.    
longitudinal separation is achieved by timing.

lateral separation can be achieved    

* by using the same or different geographic locations, sometimes called geographic separation;
* by position reports which positively indicate the ac are over different geographic locations as determined visually or by reference to a NAVAID; or
* by requiring ac to fly on specified tracks which are separated by a minimum amount appropriate to the NAVAID or method emplowed.

using VORs: lateral separation based on VOR navigation requires ac to be separated by at 15 degrees and be 15NM or more from the beacon     
using NDBs: lateral separation based on NDB navigation: 30 degrees and at least 15NM from NDB.     
using (dead recogning) DR navigation: lateral separation based on DR requires ac to be established on tracks diverging by at least 45 degrees at a distance of 15NM or more from the point of the intersection of the tracks, this point being determined either visuall or by reference to a NAVAID.

using RNAV: lateral separation based on RNAV achieved by establishing ac on traccks which diverge by at least 15 degrees.    
Lateral separation exists when the protected airspace associated with the track of one ac does not overlap with the proteted airspace associated with the track of another ac.   
This is determined by applying the angular difference between the two tracks and the appropriate protected airspace value.   
The derived value is expressed as a distance from the intersection of the tow tracks at which lateral separation exists.

DME/GNSS separation ~ DME or GNSS can be used in conjunction with other NAVAIDs and with direct controller/pilot communications.

aircraft at same level -> same track separation is 20NM provided each ac uses on-track DME stations or DME station co-located with a waypoint or the same waypoint when both ac are using GNSS and separation checked by obtinaing simultaneous DME and/or GNSS readings from the ac at frequent intervals.
This can be reduced to 10NM provided that the leading ac maintains a TAS of 20kt or faster than the trailing ac.

ac on crossing tracks the longitudinal separation applies provided each ac reports its distance from the station located at the crossing point of the tracks and the angle between the tracks is less than 90 degrees.

aircraft climbing or descending on the same track -> while vertical separation does not exist 10NM separtion is required provided each ac utilises "on-track" DME stations, an "on-track" DME station co-located with a waypoint or the same waypoint when both ac are utilising GNSS, one ac maintains a level and separation is established by obtaining simultaneous DME/GNSS reading from the ac.

ac utilising on-track DME an/or co-located waypoint or same waypoint may be cleared to climb or descend through the levels occupied by other ac and/or co-located waypoint or same waypoint, provided that tit has been positviely established that the ac have passed each other and are at least 10NM apart, or such other value prescribed by the appropriate ATS authority.

longitudinal separation estbliahed by requiring ac to depart at a specified time, to lose time to arrive over a geographical location at a specified time, or to hold over a gropgraphical location until a specified time.

For ac on the same track at the same cruising level the timed separation minima are    
* 15 minutes
* 10 minutes if NAVAIDS permit frequent determination of position and speed;
* 5 mins is preceeding ac 20kt or more faster, both ac departing from same aerodrome or reporting point;
* 3 mins, if preceeding ac is 40kt or more faster, and ac departing from same aerodrome or reported over same reporting point.

When an ac is to climb or descend through another's track, there must be 15 minutes of longitudinal separaion.   
This can be reduced to 10 minutes when NAVIDS permit frequent position determination, or 5 minutes if close to an exact reporting point.


LONGITUDINAL SEPARATION IN EUROPE ~ variation from ICAO.

ac at level, climbing, or descending, to be separated by 3 minutes provided that    
+ their progress is continuously monitored by radar; and
+ their radar separation is never less than 20NM.

reduction in separation in vicinity of aerodrome => separation in the vicinity of aerodromes reduced, if      
+ adequate separation can be provided by the aerodrome control tower when each ac is continously visible to the controller;
+ each ac is continuously visible to the flight crews of the other ac concerned and the pilots thereof report that they can maintain their own separation; or
+ if one ac follows another flight, the flight crew of the succeeding ac reports that the other ac is in sight and separation can be maintained.

### RNP

longitudinal and lateral distance-based separation minima in a RNP RNAV environment are    
+ RNP10 50NM
+ RNP4  30NM
+ otherwise 80NM with ac reporting distance "on track" from the same waypoint and separation is checked by obtaining simultaneous RNAV distance readings from the ac at frequent intervals to ensure that the minimum will not be infringed.

### Radar Separation

except under the special conditions of independent and dependent parallel approaches, the standard horozontal radar separation mimium is 5NM.   
This may be reduced to 3NM when radar capabilities at a given location permit.

Further reduction to 2.5NM may be applied between succeeding ac established on the same approach track subject to average runway occupancy time, braking action, radar rate of update, wake turbulence separation, etc.

### Clearance to Maintain Own Separation While Maintaining VMC

if requested by an ac and provided it is agreed by the pilot of the other ac, and so authorised by the appropriate ATS authority, an ACC may clear a controlled flight operating in airspace clases D an E in daylight VMC to maintain own separation to one other ac and remain in VMC.

When a controlled flight is cleared, the clearance shall be for a specified portion of the flight at or below 10.000ft, during climb or descent and subject to gurther restrictions as and when prescribed on the basis of regional air navigation agreements.


### Essential traffic information

**essential traffic** is controlled traffic not separated from other controlled traffic by the prescribed separation minima.   
ATC must advise both aircraft of    
+ direction of flight of the other ac concerned;
+ type of ac concerned; and
+ cruising level of the ac concerned and estimated time over the reporting point nearet to where the level will be crossed.


## Approach Control Service

### General Procedures for Departing Aircraft

transfer from TWR to ACS    

* when VMC in the vicinity of the aerodrome
  + prior to ac leaving vicinity of the aerodrome; or
  + prior to ac enterin IMC
* when IMS in the vicinity of the aerodrome
  + immediately before the ac entering runway in use for take-off; or
  + immediately after the ac is airborne, if local procedures require
  
Departing ac may be expedited by suggesting a take-off direction which is not into the wind.   
responsibility of PIC to accept and making such take-off or wait for normal take-of in a preferred direction.

### Clearances for Departing Aircraft

if air traffic control is based on tracks, ATC clearances must specify direction of take-off and turn after take-off, track to be made good before proceeding on desired heading, level to maintain before continuing climb to cruising level, time, point and/or rate at which level change shalle be made, and any other necessary maneuver consistent with safe operation of ac.

### Separation of Departing Aircraft

minimum separation between departing aircraft:    

* 1 minute, if ac fly on tracks diverging by at least 45 degrees.    
  minimum may be reduced for ac using parallel runways or diffrent runways with divergin directions provided they do not cross, and provided instructions covering the procedures have been approved by the appropriate ATS Authority, and lateral separation is effected immediately after take-off.
* 2 minutes, if preceeding ac is 40kt or more faster than following ac, and both ac follow same track.
* 5 minutes while vertical separation does not exist if a departing ac will be flown through the level of a preceding departing ac and both ac follow the same track.

### Information for Departing Aircraft

information regarding **significant changes** in meteorological conditions in the take-off and climb-out area obtained by the unit providing approach control service after a departing ac has established communiation with such unit, shall be tranmitted without delay, ecept when it is known that the ac has already received the information.

significant changes include surface wind direction or speed (note: magnetic wind direction is given for take-off and landing).

information regarding operational status of visual or non-visual aids essential for take-off and climb shall be transmitted without delay/unless known.

information on **essential local traffic** known to ATC

### General Procedures for Arriving Aircraft

responsibility for control of arriving ac shall be transferred from the unit providing approach control service to TWR when the ac    

* is in the vicinity of the aerodrome, and it is considered that it will be able to complete its approach and landing in visual reference to the ground, or it has reached uninterrupted VMC; or
* has landed.

... whichever is the earliest.

Arriving ac may be required to report when leaving or passing a reporting point or when starting procedures turn or base turn, or to provid other information required by the controller to expedite departing ac.

Significant changes to weather and aids during departure will be notficed to the ac asap.

### Separation of Departing and Arriving Aircraft

except otherwise prescribed, separation shall be applied when take-off clearance is based on the position of arriving ac:

if arriving ac is making a complete instrument approach, a departing ac may take-off:    
* in any direction until an arriving ac has started its procedure turn or base turn leading to final approach; or
* in a direction which id sidderent by at least 45 degrees from the reciprocal of the direction of approach after the arriving ac has started its procedure turn or base turn leading to final approach, provided that the take-off will be made at least 3 minutes before the arriving ac is estimated over the beginning of the instrument runway

if an arriving ac is making a straight-in approach, a departing ac may take-off:   
* in any direction until 5 minutes before arriving ac is estimated over instrument runway;
* in any direction which is different by at 45 degrees from the reciproval of the direction of the approach of the arriving ac
  + until 3 minutes before the arriving ac is estimate over the beginning of the runway; or
  + before the arriving ac crosses a designated fix on the approach track.
  
**own separation** ~ when requested by the ac and if so prescribed by the appropriate ATS Authority an arriving ac may be cleared to descent subjet to maintaining own separation and remaining in VMC, if reports indicate this is possible.

### Visual Approach

IFR flight may be cleared to execute a isual approach provided that the pilot can maintain visual reference to the trerrain and:    
* reported ceiling is at or above the approved initial approach level for the ac so cleared; or
* the pilot reports at the intial approach level or at any time during instrument approach peocedure that the meteorological conditions are such that with reasonable assurance a visual approach and landing can be completed.

Separation myst be provided between an ac cleared to execute a visual approach and other arriving and departing ac.


---- ac    | reported ceiling above approach level
        --
          ------> MET conditions allow visual approach
          
Instrument approaches must be conducted in accordance with IFR even if the aircraft is in VMC.     
However, the PIC may request a clearance to continue for a visual approach.

applies also to successive visual approaches, until the pilot reports having the preceding ac in sight, upon which he/she shall then be instructed to follow and maintain own separation from the precedin ac.

When both ac HEAVE WTC, or the preceding ac is heavier WTC than the following, and the distance between the ac is less than the appropriate wake turbulence minimum, the controller shall issue a caution of possible wake turbulence.

PIC of ac concerned shall be responsible for ensuring that the spacing from a preceding ac of a heavier wake turbulence category is acceptable.   
If additional spacing is required, the flight crew shall inform ATC accordingly, stating their requirements.


### Instrument Approach

PIC reports or it is clearly apparant to ATC that crew is not familiar with an instrument approach procedure, the initial approach level, the point (in minutes from the appropriate reporting point) at which the procedure turn will be started, the level at which the procedures turn shall be carried out, and the final approach track shall be specified, except that only the last-mentioned need be specified if the ac is to be cleared for a straight in approach.    
The missed approach procedures shall be specified when deemed necessary.

A *timed approach procedure* may be used, as necessary, in order to expedite the approaches of a number of arriving ac. 
In a timed approach procedure ac are requested to pass a specified point inbound at a notified time.

If visual reference to terrain is established before the approach procedures is complete, the pilot must continue with the full procedure unless he or she requests and is cleared for a visual approach.

### Holding

holding and holding pattern entry shall be accomplished in accordance with procedures established by the approiate ATS Authority and published in the relevant AIP.    
If entry and holding procedures have not been published or if the procedures are not known to the PIC, the appropriate ATC unit shall describe the procedures to be followed.

Levels at holding points should be assigned so that -- normally the first ac to arrive over a holding point  should be at the lowest level, with following ac at successively higher levels. <--> stack!

### Approach Sequence

approach sequence ~ facilitate maximum number of arrivals with least average delay.   

Special priority may be given    

* an ac with anticipates being compelled to land because of factors affecting the safe operation of the ac (engine failure, shortage of fuel, etc); or
* hospital ac or ac carrying any sick or seriously injured person requiring urgent medical attention.

If pilot in an approach sequence has indicated an intention to hold for weather improvement, or for other reasons, such action shall be approved.    
However, when other holding ac indicate intention to continue their approach-to-land and if alternative procedures involving, for instance, the use of radar are not available, the pilot desiring to hold will be cleared to an adjacent fix for holding awaiting weather change or rerouting.    
Alternatively, the ac should be given a clearance to place it at the top of the approach sequence so that other holding ac may be permitted to land.

Coordination shall be effected with the area control centre when required to avoid conflict with the traffic under the jurisdiction of this centre. The ac operator, or a designated representative, shall be advised of the action taken immediately after the clearance is issued, if practicable.


### Expected Approach Time

**expected approach time** is the time at which ATC expects that an arriving ac, following a delay, will leave the holding point to complete its approach for a landing.

EAT will be determined for an arriving ac that will be subjected to a *delay of 10 minutes of more*.   
EAT must be transmitted to the ac asap and not later than at the commencement of its initial descent from cruising level.

If ac is expected to *hold for 30 minutes or more*, the EAT must be transmitted by the most expeditious means.    

A revised EAT must be transmmitted to the ac without delay whenever EAT changes by 5 minutes or more.

If the holding point to which the EAT refers is not obvious, it should be specified.

### Information for Arriving Aircraft

arriving ac shall asap establish communiation with approach controle unit

to be transmitted, unless known to have already received:

* runway in use;
* meteorological information (magnetic wind direcetion is given for take-off and landing)
* current ruwnay sufrace conditions; and
* changes in observed RBR or other measure of visibility.

At the commencement of the final approach, the following information shall be transmitted:     
* significant changes in the mean surface wind direction and speed;
* latest information, if any, on wind shear and/or turbulence in the final approach area; and
* current visibility.

wind direction is normally "TRUE", but ATC will always give the surface wind in "MAGNETIC

### Final Approach

During final approach the following information shall be transmitted without delay:

* sudden occurrence of hazards (e.g. unauthorised traffic on the ruwnay);
* significant variations in the currrent surface wind, expresssed in terms of minimum and maximum values, significant changes are
  + mean headwind component: 10kt
  + mean tailwind component: 2 kt
  + mean crosswind component: 5kt
* significant changes in runway surface conditions;
* changes in the operational status of required visual or non-visual aids; and
* changes in observed RVR value(s), in accordance with the reporte scale in use, or changes in the visibility representative of the direction of approach and landing.

### Inability to Comply with Procedure

PIC advises on inability to comply with the approach control holding or communication procedures, the alternative procedures should be approached if known traffic conditions permit.



## Aerodrome Control Service

### Functions of Aerodrome Control Tower

TWR -> information and clearance for safe, orderly, and expeditious flow of air traffic on and in the vicinity of an aerodrome with the objective to prevent collision(s) between:    

* aircraft flying in the aerodrome traffic circuits 
* aircraft operating on the maneuvering area;
* aircraft landing and taking-off;
* aircraft and vehicles operationg on the maneuvering area; or
* aircraft on the maneuvering area and obstractions on that area.

### Alerting Service Provided By Aerodrome Control Tower

TWR responsible for altering the safety services and must immediately report any failure or irregularity of operation in any apparatus, lgiht, or other device established at an aerodrome for the guidance of aerodrome traffic and PICs of ac.

Aircraft with fail to report after having been handed over  to the TWR, or, having once reported, cease radio contant, and in either case fail to land five minutes after the expected landing time, must be reported to the area control center or flight information center.

### Suspension of VFR Operations

in case of suspension of VFR operations, TWR    

* hold all departure other than those which file an IFR flight plan and obtain approval thereof from the aera control center;
* recall all local flights operating under VFR or obtain approval for special VFR operations;
* notify the area control center of the action taken; and
* notify all operators of the reason for taking such action, if necessary or requested.

### Information on Local Traffic

information on local traffic shall be issued either directly or through the unit providing approach control service when, in the judgement of the TWR controller, such information is necessary in the interests of safety, or when requested by aircraft.

### Information on Aerodrome Conditions

essential information on aerodrome conditions includes information on the following:    

* construction or maintenance work on, or immediately adjacent to the movement area;
* rough or broken surfaces on a runway, a taxiway, or an apron, whther marked or not;
* snow, slush, or ice on the runway, taxiway, or an apron;
* water on a runway, taxiway, or an apron;
* snow banks or drifts adjacent to a ruwnay, taxiway, or an apron;
* other temporary hazards, including parked ac and birds on the ground or in the air; and
* failure or irregular operation of part or all of the aerodrome lighting system; or any other pertinent information.

### ATIS

aerodrome information may be provided by a voice ATIS as a continuous or repetitive transmission.   
A discrete VHF frequency is used whenever practicable, but, if one is not available, the transmission may be made on the voice channel of an appropriate terminal vavigation aid, preferably a VOR, but not on the voice channel of the ILS.

information must relate to only 1 aerodrome.   
information must be updated immediately given a significant change.    
Preparation and dissemination of the ATIS message is the responsibility of ATS.    
ATIS broadcast should, whenever practicable, not exceed 30 seconds.

Individual ATIS messages are identified by a designator in form of a letter of the ICAO spelling alphabet, in alphabetical order.   
Ac to acknowledge receipt of information upon establishing communication with ATS unit providing approach control srevice or aerodrome control service, as appropriate.   
When acknowledging receipt, ATS unit will confirm the altimeter setting but isnot required to repeat any other information unless the ATIS message received is out of datae and then only the elements which have changed will be transmitted to the ac.

When rapidly changing meteorological conditions make it inadvisable to inclde a weather report in the ATIS, the TIS message will indivate tha the relevant weather information will be given on initail contact iwth the appropriate ATS unit.


### Control of Aerodrome Traffic

ac landing or in the final stages of an approach to land shall normally have priority over an ac intending to depart.

Priority for landing will be given to 

* emergency
* hospital flight;
* search and rescue ac on operation.

Clearance to land or any alternative clearance received from the aerodrome controller, or - when applicable - the procedural controller should normally be passed to the ac before it reaches a distance of 4km(2NM) from touchdown.

If an ac enters the circuit without permission and indicats that it wishs to land, it must be allowed to do so.   
In particular, controllers should be aware that ac experiencing an emergency might enter the circuit without permission and they should be ready to offer assistance.

Departure shall normally be cleared in the order in which they are ready for take-off, except that deviations may be made from this order of priority to facilitate the maximum number of departures with the least average delay.

Landing ac priority over take-offs!

### Control of Departing Aircraft

departing ac will not be permitted to commence take-off until the preceding departing ac has crossed the end of the runway in use or has started a turn or until all preceding landing aircraft are clear of the runway in use.

In the interest of expediting air traffic, a clearance for immediate take-off may be issued to an aircraft before it enters the runway.    
On acceptance of such clearrance the ac shall taxy out to the ruwnay and take-off in one continuous movement.

Independent parallel departures may be conducted from parallel runways provided there is suitable surveillance readar available capable ofidentifying ac within 1NM from the end of the runway.

### Control of Arriving Aircraft

landing ac will not be permitted to cross the beginning of the runway on its final approach until the preceding departing ac has crossed the end of the runway in use, or has started a turn, or unitl all preceding ladning ac are clear of the runway in use.


## ATC Surveillance Service

ATC surveillance service of air traffic from either radar or automatic dependent surveillance ADS.

radar ~ primary radar/surveillance (reflections / echo principle)   
secondary radar/surveillance ~ active response from ac transponder

ADS transmits, as a minimum: GPS position, speed, height and heading.   
ADS-B (broadcast) ~ basis data unsolicited on SSR reply frequency to whoever can receive    
ADS-C (controct) ~ datalink service transmitting additional information, including clearance requests and messages. ATC can reply through datalink with clearances and control message,(voiceless control)

### Radar System Capabilities

radar ~ high level of reliability, availability, and integrity; back-up facilities are always provided.

Radar services are restricted to specific areas of coverage within line-of-sight of the radar transmitter.   
Thus, remote areas are unlikely to provide a radar service and air traffic will be procedural control.

When ATC is equipped with/using PSR, the pilot of a departing ac can expect his ac to be identified within 1 NM of the departure end of runway.

### Minimum Radar Information

minimum radar information displayed to controller is

* radar position indications;
* radar map information; and
* information from SSR Mode A, Mode C, and MOde S, when available.

### Identification of Aircraft

ac must be radar identified and the pilot informed before a radar service can be provided. Radar identification is achieved using SSR by

* use of a radar identification label;
* setting a specific code; or
* using the IDENT feature.

using PSR by    
* correlating radar position with ac reported position;
* transfer of radar identification;
* observing ac reported maneuvers; or
* instructing the ac to change haeding by 30 degrees or more.

The term radar contact is used by a controller to an aircraft means that the aircraft has been positively identified on radar, but it does not mean that the radar controller is offering an specific service.   
Before offering a service the radar controller must confirm that the ac has been positively identified on radar and he must also confirm the type of srevice given.

### Position Information

An ac provided with radar service should be informed of its position in the following circumstances:   

* upon identification, except when the identification is established:
  + based on the pilot's report of the ac position or withini on NM of the runway upon departure and the observation is consistent with the ac's time of departure;
  + by use of assigned discrete SSR codes or Mode S and the location of the ac observed radar position indication is consistent with the currrent flight plan of the ac; or
  + by transfer of radar identification;
  + on request;
* when a pilot's estimate differes significantly from the readar controller's estimation based on radar observation;
when the pilot is instructed to resume own navigation after radar vectoring if current instructions had diverted the ac form a prviously assigned route; or
* immediately before termination of radar srevice, if the ac is observed to deviate from its intended route.


ATC advises pilots that they have radar contact to confirm that the radar identity of the ac has been established.

Postion information will be passed to ac in one  of the following forms:

* well-known geopgraphical position
* magnetic track and distance to a significant point, an enroute NAVAID, or an approach aid;
* direction (using points of compasses) and distance from a known position;
* distance to touchdown, if the ac is on final approach; or
distance and direction fromthe center line of an ATS route.

### Strayed and Unidentified Aircraft

**strayed aircraft** ~ an ac which has deviated significantly fom it sintended track or reports that it is lost;     
**unidentified aircraft** ~ an aircraft which has been observed or reported to be operating in a given area but whose identity has not been established.

### Radar Vectoring

radar vectoring ~ giving pilot specific headings to maintain a desired track.

when vectoring

* whenever practicable - vectoring along routes or tracks on which pilot can monitor ac position with reference to NAVAIDs
* when vector divert from previously assigned route, provide information unless self-evident
* ac shall not be vectored closer than 2.5NM from limit of airapsce for which radar controller is responsible, unless local arrangements exist or transfer to adjacent sector
* controlled flights not be vectored into uncontrolled airspace ecept in emergency or to circumnavigate sever weather, or at request of pilot
* when vectoring IFR flight, the radar controller shall issue clearances such that the prescribed obstacle clearance will exist at all times until the ac reaches the point where the pilot will resum own navigation.

When terminating radar vectoring, the radar controller shall instruct the aircrew to resume own navigation, given the ac's position and appropriate instructions as necessary, if vectoring diverted ac from previously assigned route.

### Radar Vectoring to ILS

vectors ~ magnetic headings to maintain the desired track.    
Final vector to enable ac to be established in level flight on final approach track prior to intercepting the specified or nominal glide path, if an ILS or radar approach is to be made, and should provide an intercept angle with the final approach track of 45 degrees of less

When independent parallel approaches are being used, the maximum intercept angle is 30 degrees and the ac should be established on the center line at least 2NM before glideslop intercept.

### Surveillance Radar Approaches

surveillance radar approaches are normally terminated at 2NM from touchdown or before an ac enters an area of permanent radar clutter.   
When authorised, surveillance radar appaoches may be continued to the threshold of the runway, or a prescribed point less than 2NM from touchdown.   
Distance and level information should be given at each 0.5NM.

During a surveillance radar approach:    
* distance and level information should be given at each 0.5 NM;
* transmission should not be interrupted for intervals of more than 5 seconds while ac is within a distance of 4NM from touchdown; and
* radar controller should not be responsible for any duries other than those directly connected with a particular approach.

An ac making a radar approach should be directed to exectue a missed approach, if    
* ac appears to be dangerously positioned on final approach; or
* for reasons involving traffic conflcitions;
* if no clearance to land has been received from the no-radar controller  at 2NM from touchdown or such distance has been agreed with the TWR; or
* on instructions from the aerodrome controller.

An ac making a radar approach should be advised to consider executing a missed approach in the following circumstances:   

* when the ac reaches a position from which it appear that a successful approach cannot be completed;
if the ac is not visiable on the radar dispaly for any significant interval during the last 2NM of the approach; or
* if the position of the ac is in doubt during any portion of the final approach.

In all such cases the reason for the instruction or advice shall be given to the pilot.

### Transfer of Control

transfer of control from one controller to another will only take place when the accepting controller has confirmed to the transferring controller that the ac has been positively identified.

### Wakte Turbulence Radar Separation Minima

different wake turbulence separation minima in different States.    

ICAO requires in approach and departure phase    

* an ac is operting directly behind another ac at the same altitude or less than 1000ft below;
* both ac are using the same runway, or parallel runways separated by less than 760m; or
* an ac is crossing behind another ac, at the same altitude or less than 1000ft below.
